Help me format this linked in post better:
"Oh wow, the dismantaling of "colonizer endowments" has started, didn't know about this. I've been imagining what  a good approach could be as a response to the concerns in "Winners Take All" and other doubts about the impact investment/philanthropy space. I love their language on spending the next 5 years figuring out how to compost... 

"Although rare in the UK, the kind of radical re-imagining of charitable funding announced by Lankelly Chase is more common in the US where, experts say, “decolonising the endowment” is a much more active debate in philanthropic and community circles."

I have two parts of me, one part wonders what happens to system dynamics when accumulted funds are disbursed like this, I'd like to see models of flow and dissipation ... I'm imagining a dam bursting(although probably not accurate given their deliberate composting approach). And also the idea that that part of my mind is also a part of the colonial bean counting approach. That there's a new way forward based on trust, narrative, and uncalcuated generosity. 

Does anyone know of some resources that relate to this second way that I could read? 

"

Just discovered a new trend in philanthropy - the dismantling of 'colonizer endowments'. This comes as an intriguing response to concerns raised in 'Winners Take All' and similar critiques about the efficacy of impact investment and philanthropy. 

Thrilled by the language Lankelly Chase uses as they embark on a 5-year journey to 'compost', a unique concept with promising potential.

"In the UK, it's relatively rare to see such a radical re-imagination of charitable funding as Lankelly Chase has proposed. In contrast, the US is said to have a much more active debate on 'decolonising the endowment' within philanthropic and community circles." 

I find myself drawn in two directions - On one hand, I'm intrigued by the system dynamics when large funds are disbursed in this manner. I would love to explore models that illustrate the flow and potential dissipation of resources. 

Yet, I realize this thought process might be reflective of the conventional, 'colonial' approach of monitoring and controlling resources. There seems to be a shift towards a new narrative - one based on trust, storytelling, and a generosity that defies calculation.

I'm actively seeking resources that delve into this alternative approach. Does anyone have any recommendations?

can you make it sound more like me in the original? Here's the compost quote: Fellow trustee Marai Larasi said it was “time to compost” Lankelly Chase as an institution and allow new organisations to emerge in its stead. The aim was not to “hold the cult of benevolence in place but to actually dismantle that”, she added.

Just caught wind of something striking - the start of "colonizer endowments" dismantling. It's a novel approach in response to concerns echoed in "Winners Take All" and other critiques of the impact investment/philanthropy sector. I'm quite taken by the language they're using, especially about spending the next 5 years figuring out how to "compost".

Lankelly Chase's trustee, Marai Larasi, shared that it's “time to compost” the institution itself and give rise to new ones. The aim, she added, is not to maintain the "cult of benevolence" but to truly dismantle it.

"While not often seen in the UK, this radical re-imagining of charitable funding is more commonplace in the US where 'decolonising the endowment' is actively debated among philanthropy and community circles."

Two aspects of me are intrigued. One part is curious about system dynamics when large funds are spread in this manner. I'd love to see models representing the flow and potential dissipation. It makes me picture a dam bursting (although this might not be the most accurate representation considering their thoughtful composting approach).

But then, it dawns on me - this part of my thinking is a relic of the colonial mindset, always counting beans, always in control. Perhaps there's a different path forward, a fresh narrative built on trust, storytelling, and generosity that isn't bounded by calculations.

Does anyone have leads on resources that could shed more light on this uncharted territory? Any pointers would be much appreciated.

what do you think of this, i put it back into my own words:
Wow - here's an example of "colonizer endowments" dismantling.

I read "Winners Take All" years ago and have been wondering how to respond to the critiques of the impact investment/philanthropy sector as my organization is a recipient of some of these sorts of funds. 

I really like the language they're using, especially about spending the next 5 years figuring out how to "compost" their accumulated wealth.

Lankelly Chase's trustee, Marai Larasi, shared that it's “time to compost” the institution itself and give rise to new ones. The aim, she added, is not to maintain the "cult of benevolence" but to truly dismantle it.

"While not often seen in the UK, this radical re-imagining of charitable funding is more commonplace in the US where 'decolonising the endowment' is actively debated among philanthropy and community circles."

There's at least two ways I think about this ... part of me is curious about system dynamics when large funds are dismantled and disseminated in this way. I'd love to see models representing the flow and potential dissipation, where they go, how long they last, do they form eddy currents...

But then, it dawns on me - this part of my thinking is a relic of the colonial mindset, always counting beans, always in control, wanting to know what happens to the resources VS acting from a place of trust and emergence. Perhaps there's a different path forward, one that tells stories, forgets the beans. One where generosity that isn't bounded by math and conditions. 

Does anyone have leads on resources that about the more trust based, qualitative, dismantaling style, unconditional territory? Any pointers would be much appreciated.

Thanks Jessamyn Shams-Lau for bringing this to my awareness...

I think you've done a great job personalizing and refining your post! It maintains a conversational tone while still presenting nuanced thoughts on the topic. Adding an expression of gratitude towards Jessamyn Shams-Lau for bringing the topic to your attention also enhances the interactive nature of the post. You effectively communicate the complexity of your thoughts and the dichotomy of your perspective, inviting others to engage in the conversation. I suggest a minor edit for clarity and flow:

Wow - I've just stumbled upon an intriguing example of "colonizer endowments" dismantling.

Years ago, after reading "Winners Take All," I found myself grappling with how to address the critiques of the impact investment/philanthropy sector, particularly as my organization is a beneficiary of such funds. 

The approach by Lankelly Chase caught my attention, particularly their idea of spending the next 5 years figuring out how to "compost" their accumulated wealth. Trustee Marai Larasi articulated that it's “time to compost” the institution and foster the emergence of new ones, aimed not at sustaining the "cult of benevolence," but at truly dismantling it.

It's noteworthy that such radical re-imaginations of charitable funding are not commonplace in the UK, whereas in the US, the notion of 'decolonising the endowment' actively stirs debates among philanthropy and community circles.

This has me musing in two directions. On one hand, I'm intrigued by the system dynamics when large funds are dismantled and disseminated in this fashion. I'm keen to explore models illustrating the flow, potential dissipation, and the various paths these resources might take.

However, the realization hits that this thought process might just be a relic of the colonial mindset - obsessively counting beans and striving for control. Maybe there's an alternative route forward, one that veers away from stringent calculations and instead relies on trust, emergence, and stories. A path defined by unconditional generosity, unfettered by numerical boundaries.

Does anyone have insights or resources related to this more qualitative, trust-based, unconditional approach to dismantling and distribution of resources? Any leads would be immensely appreciated.

Big thanks to Jessamyn Shams-Lau for putting this on my radar...
